vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/b9f6da03-450d-478f-a00e-f90519b28213">WHOLESALE TRADE</keyword>         <topcClas>Income, property and investment - Economics</topcClas>         <topcClas>Economic conditions and indicators - Economics</topcClas>         <topcClas>General - Employment and labour</topcClas>         <topcClas>Trade, industry and markets - Industry and management</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p>The <i>Annual Respondents Database</i> (ARD) is constructed from a compulsory business survey. Until 1997 it was created out of the <i>Annual Censuses of Production and Construction</i> (ACOP and ACOC); these were combined into the <i>Annual Business Inquiry</i> (ABI) in 1998. The ARD is a census of large businesses, and a sample of smaller ones. Smaller firms may receive a "short form". These do not require detailed breakdowns of totals. Hence for certain variables the values may be imputed from third party sources or estimated rather than returned by respondents.<br> <br> This dataset is created for the Economic Analysis and Satellite Accounts Division for research purposes. To create the ARD, the other surveys are converted into a single consistent format linked by the Inter-Departmental Business Register references over time. Northern Ireland data is held up to 2001. From 2002, the ABI is collected and stored separately in Northern Ireland. Special permission is required to use new NI ABI data.<br> <br> <i>ABI background</i><br> The ABI is the financial information survey conducted by the Office for National Statistics (ONS).  This is a statutory survey conducted under the Statistics of Trade Act 1947.  Organisations are obliged under this legislation to provide a response. Businesses are sampled from the ONS business register current at the time of drawing the sample:  first the CSO Business Register, which ran until 1993; then the Inter-Departmental Business Register, which has run from 1994 onwards. The ONS holds firms' responses to the ABI in the Annual Respondents Database (ARD).<br> <br> The ABI replaced the following annual survey systems in 1998:<ul><li><i>Annual Employment Survey</i> (AES)</li><li><i>Annual Censuses of Production and Construction</i> (ACOP/ACOC), which include the <i>Purchases Inquiry</i> (PI)</li><li>The six annual Distribution and Services (DSI) inquiries (<i>Annual Wholesale Inquiry</i>; <i>Annual Retail Inquiry</i>; <i>Annual Motor Trades Inquiry</i>; <i>Annual Catering Inquiry</i>; <i>Annual Property Inquiry</i>; and <i>Annual Service Trades Inquiry</i></li></ul>Until 1997 the data were limited to the production and construction industries surveyed by the ACOP and ACOC (construction from 1993 only). The incorporation of the DSI inquiries for six additional sectors is reflected in the number of individual business contributors rising from approximately 15,000 for 1980 to 1996 to approximately 50,000 for 1997/98 and to over 70,000 for 1999.<br> <br> The ABI is one of the most comprehensive surveys undertaken of business organisations in the UK, covering over 100 key economic variables, and approximately two-thirds of the UK economy. Detailed variables for turnover, employment, costs, capital and the derivation of sales and profits are included.  A firm-level measure of Gross Value Added (GVA) is also generated so that the productivity of organisations can be evaluated.<br> <br> The ABI samples UK businesses and other such establishments according to their employment size and industry sector.  It is a census of large businesses, and a stratified sample of small and medium sized enterprises. The stratified sampling framework means that smaller firms move in and out of the survey.  The forms are customised for industry sectors and sub-sectors.  The statistics produced from the sample data are used primarily to assist in the generation of the National Accounts and the measurement of Gross Domestic Product (GDP).<br> <br> A number of different form-types are used in the survey. Long form-types are sent to all businesses with an employment of 250 or more and also to a proportion of selected businesses with lower employment. Short form-types are sent to the remaining selected businesses. The forms differ in that long form-types ask for a detailed breakdown of purchases; employment costs; taxes, duties and levies etc, whereas short form-types just ask for the totals of these variables.<br> <br> The data are collected in two parts: Part 1 is an employment record, collected as soon as possible after 12th December. Part 2 is for financial information, which may be submitted up to twelve months after the financial year end.<br> <br> <i>Geographical references: postcodes</i><br> The postcodes available in these data are pseudo-anonymised postcodes.  The real postcodes are not available due to the potential risk of identification of the observations.  However, these replacement postcodes retain the inherent nested characteristics of real postcodes, and will allow researchers to aggregate observations to other geographic units, e.g. wards, super output areas, etc. In the dataset, the variable of the replacement postcode is 'new_PC'.  Users who specifically require postcodes to undertake their analyses are advised to read the ONS document <a href=" http://securedata.data-archive.ac.uk/media/19702/geographicalreferencesons.pdf" title="Geographical references in the Virtual Microdata Laboratory and Secure Data Service"> Geographical references in the Virtual Microdata Laboratory and Secure Data Service</a> before applying for access to the data.<br> <br> <i>Linking to other business studies</i><br> These data contain Inter-Departmental Business Register reference numbers.  These are anonymous but unique reference numbers assigned to business organisations.  Their inclusion allows researchers to combine different business survey sources together.  Researchers may consider applying for other business data to assist their research.<br> <br> <i>ARD, the Annual Business Survey (ABS) and the Business Register and Employment Survey (BRES)</i><br> The ABI, Part 2 (ABI/2) was replaced by the ABS in 2009. The ABI, Part 1 (ABI/1) was replaced by the BRES in 2009. The BRES data for 2009 onwards are held separately under UK Data Archive SN 7463. ABS data for 2008 onwards are held under UK Data Archive SN 7451. Researchers who are applying for access to the ARD and who require data for 2009 onwards are recommended to also apply for the ABS data under SN 7451.<br> <br> </abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br>The contents of the data can be divided into the following sections:<ul><li>employment</li><li>turnover and sales</li><li>purchases</li><li>stocks, capital expenditure and investment</li><li>retail</li><li>other expenditure and income</li></ul>Detailed variables within the above headings are customised according to the following broad industrial sectors into which the data are divided:<ul><li>production</li><li>construction</li><li>property</li><li>motor trades</li><li>catering</li><li>retailing</li><li>wholesale</li><li>services</li></ul>Standard measure: Gross Value Added (GVA).  This is the sum of outputs minus the sum of inputs for a company i.e. income generated less intermediate consumption of goods and services used.<br/></abstract>       <sumDscr>         <timePrd event="start" date="1973-01-01T00:00:00Z">1973</timePrd>         <timePrd event="end" date="2008-01-01T00:00:00Z">2008</timePrd>         <nation>Great Britain</nation>         <nation>United Kingdom</nation>         <geogUnit>Counties</geogUnit>         <geogUnit>Government Office Regions</geogUnit>         <geogUnit>LAU-2 Areas</geogUnit>         <geogUnit>Local Authority Districts</geogUnit>         <geogUnit>NUTS-III Areas</geogUnit>         <geogUnit>Postcode (Unit) [anonymised]</geogUnit>         <geogUnit>Training and Enterprise Councils</geogUnit>         <geogUnit>Travel to Work Areas</geogUnit>         <geogUnit>Unitary Authorities (England)</geogUnit>         <geogUnit>Unitary Authorities (Wales)</geogUnit>         <geogUnit>Wards (Electoral)</geogUnit>         <geogUnit>Westminster Parliamentary Constituencies</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>Institutions/organisations</anlyUnit>         <universe>National</universe>         <universe>Businesses in Great Britain (and Northern Ireland prior to 2002) registered for VAT and/or PAYE in 1973-2008.</universe>         <dataKind>Alpha/numeric data</dataKind>         <dataKind> Individual (micro) level</dataKind>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <timeMeth>Repeated cross-sectional study</timeMeth>         <timeMeth>Annual</timeMeth>         <dataCollector>Office for National Statistics</dataCollector>         <sampProc>One-stage stratified or systematic random sample</sampProc>         <sampProc>all large businesses surveyed; subsets of medium and small businesses sampled; survey population stratified by SIC(2007), employment and country</sampProc>         <deviat>Approximately 60,000 - 75,000 businesses; approximately 15,000 prior to 1997</deviat>         <collMode>Postal survey</collMode>         <sources />         <weight>Weighting used. See documentation for details</weight>         <cleanOps>B</cleanOps>       </dataColl>     </method>     <dataAccs>       <setAvail>         <accsPlac>UK Data Service</accsPlac>       </setAvail>       <useStmt>         <specPerm>Secure data</specPerm>         <restrctn>Registration is required and standard conditions of use apply. The depositor may be informed about usage. Controlled data requirements and conditions also apply. Further information is available from <a href='http://ukdataservice.ac.uk/get-data/how-to-access/accesssecurelab.aspx'>Access to the Secure Lab</a>. In addition, the Service is required to request explicit permission from the data owner prior to providing the researcher with access to the data.<br> Available to UK HE/FE applicants only. <p>Please note:<br>Since these data are more sensitive and/or pose a higher risk of disclosure than data made available under the standard End User Licence or under a Special Licence, they are not available for download but may be accessed through Secure Access. Access requires accreditation by the UK Statistics Authority as an Approved Researcher, completion of face-to-face training, and agreement to the Secure Access's <a href='http://ukdataservice.ac.uk/media/176858/ukda140_sds_sdsagreement_public.pdf'>User Agreement</a> and <a href='http://ukdataservice.ac.uk/media/176861/UKDA142_SDS_SecurityBreaches_public.pdf'>Breaches Penalties Policy</a>. This is to ensure that the guarantee of confidentiality given to survey respondents is protected. Applications are screened by the UK Data Archive and the Office for National Statistics, and access is only granted to those researchers requiring data for statistical research purposes and who can justify their need for the data. Users who obtain access to these data are required to read and follow the <a href='http://www.data-archive.ac.uk/media/132701/UKDA171-SS-MicrodataHandling.pdf'> Microdata Handling and Security: Guide to Good Practice</a>.</restrctn>         <contact><a href=http://www.ukdataservice.ac.uk/help/get-in-touch.aspx>Get in touch</a></contact>       </useStmt>     </dataAccs>     <othrStdyMat>       <relStdy>6699 UK Innovation Survey, 1994-2012: Secure Access </relStdy>       <relStdy>6839 Workplace Employment Relations Survey: Annual Respondents Database Linked Datasets, 2002-2004: Secure Access </relStdy>       <relStdy>7451 Annual Business Survey, 2008-2013: Secure Access </relStdy>       <relStdy>7463 Business Register and Employment Survey, 2009-2013: Secure Access </relStdy>       <relPubl>   </relPubl>       <relPubl>Riley, R.
